awd_titl_txt: An Online International Methods Colloquium for Quantitative Methodology in Political Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops, organizes, and produces a weekly interactive online seminar on the use of quantitative and statistical analysis in social research, particularly political science. This project will leverage off-the-shelf, commercially-proven technology to bring methodologists in political science and allied fields into interactive conversation with scholars, students, policy makers, and industry practitioners all over the world without travel or venue costs for the participants. The goals of the project are to promote the development and application of new quantitative techniques for data analysis that are applicable to the study of social, behavioral, and economic phenomena, to enable low-cost collaboration and discussion among scholars and professionals around the world who are actively involved in the development and application of quantitative analysis in the social and economic sciences, government, and industry, and to provide a free educational resource for students, practitioners, and policy makers interested in using quantitative analysis and social scientific research design.

Participation will be free of charge, requiring only a computing device (smart phone, tablet, or computer) and an internet connection. Scholars and students will benefit from interaction with and instruction from colleagues at the forefront of the field. The archive of videos from past colloquia will form a reference library of methodological resources for teaching and research. People working outside academia will have the opportunity to learn from new research as a part of their continuing education, and to contribute their practical knowledge to the scholarly conversation. In addition to the direct benefits of collaborative research and scholarship promoted by the colloquium, this project addresses an urgent requirement for future U.S. economic growth and technological advancement. This project will help to grow the community of experts in the analysis of social and economic data that is critical to the future health of the American economy.  This project will provide a free resource for students and data scientists in industry to expand their quantitative skills, giving them an opportunity to interact closely with the scholarly community and learn advanced techniques.

por.por_cntn:
The International Methods Colloquium (IMC) aimed to establish a forum where social scientists could present research relevant to quantitative scientific methodology to, and receive helpful feedback from, an international audience at low cost. Because most departments of political science have at most one methodologist, the opportunity for these scholars to stay at the forefront of their field and interact with one another are limited. The IMC makes this possible by eliminating the travel, technological, and administrative costs. It also provides a public archive of scholarly research talks when scientists cannot attend the talk in person (or wish to use a talk for educational purposes in a future class or seminar); this archive is accessible from https://www.methods-colloquium.com/ or the associated YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC86eeR0OyCLvtyGBd4RJDNQ.

The goals of the project were met in full. The first IMC talk was given on January 30, 2015 (by Princeton faculty member Kosuke Imai) and was attended by 74 people, all at their home institutions. Since that time, we have hosted 41 talks by 41 different scholars from political science and beyond in five seasons of speakers (corresponding to five academic semesters since the program's inception). The IMC's speakers have included Gary King, Adrian Raftery, E.J. Wagenmakers, Phil Schrodt, Justin Grimmer, Andrew Gelman, and many other scholars at all levels of seniority and on a variety of methodologically-engaged topics.

Attendance figures for the first three seasons of the IMC were reported in a forthcoming publication for PS: Political Science and Politics entitled "Blogs, Online Seminars, and Social Media as Tools of Scholarship in Political Science;" this paper was co-authored by two IMC personnel (including the PI) and was supported by our grant. In the first three IMC seasons, we recorded live attendance broadly similar to panel attendance at a large national conference. Each panel recorded between ~10-40 attendees, with a few panels attracting over 60 live attendees. In addition to strong live attendance, we recorded hundreds of people viewing each recording afterward: based on the analysis in our paper, a seminar with a live audience of ≈ 30 can expect ≈ 200 later views on YouTube. The IMC has continued to attract viewers in subsequent seasons not covered by our initial evaluation. This season (Fall 2017), we had our highest live attendance yet (247 live attendees) for our "Roundtable on Reproducibility and a Stricter Threshold for Statistical Significance." Even more impressively, our YouTube recordings have been extensively viewed: as of this writing, the repository of past videos has been viewed 30,020 times and has 557 subscribers updated to new videos! 

 

As a project committed to the communication and discussion of new research across the methods community, the IMC's impact should be measured by how well it helps other researchers disseminate their research. Of course, the most impressive viewership numbers are garnered by the researchers who already have the most visibility and the strongest reputation. For example, Gary King's talk from September 2015 on "Why Propensity Scores Should Not Be Used for Matching" has been viewed nearly 15,000 times on YouTube. Andrew Gelman's talk from October 2016 on "The Statistical Crisis in Science" has been viewed over 2,600 times. But the IMC also helps lesser-known and junor scholars get attention for and feedback on their work. As one example, Zach Jones (a graduate student from Penn State) gave a talk on "Data Mining as Exploratory Data Analysis" that has been viewed 778 times on YouTube.  Jane Lawrence Sumner (an assistant professor at the University of Minnesota) had her talk on "Measuring Personalism in Non-Democracies" viewed 109 times on YouTube.

In conclusion, since its first talk in 2015, the IMC has become an important outlet for methodologically-inclined researchers in the social scientists to learn about new work and present their own research for dissemination and feedback. The project continues to recruit new speakers, and is anticipated to continue into the foreseeable future despite the end of NSF funding. It has achieved the goals set out in the grant, and appears poised to continue to meet or exceed those goals over the next few years.
